entry.title: Use REST services in Graph
entry.content:
Hello!

In this part of the tutorial on Graph we will focus on the support of REST services in Graph. For an overview of other parts of this series, check out the Information Map.

REST support in Graph

Graph enables the use of REST services as data sources for business data graphs (BDGs). Compared to OData data sources, there are some key differences:

  • The metadata that describes the service must be provided separately along with the service endpoint in the OpenAPI format.
  • OpenAPI does not have the concept of entities like OData does. Instead, it focuses on operations, which are represented as actions and functions in a BDG.

We will now explain how these differences are being handled by Graph in more detail:

Metadata for a REST service

REST services are commonly described using the OpenAPI format, which outlines the operations and resources available in the service. Unlike OData, which provides a $metadata endpoint for accessing service metadata, plain REST services do not have a standard way to access this information. Since Graph requires metadata to work with REST services, users must provide this metadata when setting up a business data graph.

Graph uses BTP destinations to define access to data sources. To use a REST service as data source, users need to create 2 destinations:

  • a data destination: that points to the actual REST service
  • a metadata destination: where the OpenAPI metadata document for the REST service can be retrieved

Both destinations also need annotations that connect them together, so that Graph can understand which metadata destination belongs to which REST service destination.

Data Model

Graph exposes a unified API endpoint for the OData and GraphQL protocols. Both offer an entity (or type/object) model in which data can be represented. Plain REST as described by OpenAPI does not have a strict entity model, and services are defined as different operations. For example, an operation might be to 'find a pet by name' or 'retrieve pets of a store' in a pet-store service. However, to expose these REST-operations as valid OData in the unified API, Graph transforms them into unbound OData operations (actions & functions) in the BDG. We refer to these also as mirrored operations, similar to mirrored entities. As part of that transformation, some changes are made to the signature of the operations to align with the OData standard. These include:

  • all paths are flattened: for example a GET /users/pets is transformed to a GET users_pets in the BDG
  • all methods are standardized to GET and POST, with the underlying method being appended to the operation name: for example a DELETE /users/pets becomes a POST /users_pets__delete

Example

Having explained the main concepts of REST support in Graph, let's now look at a practical example. We will take the try-out sandbox of this SAP Ariba Network Catalog Management REST service and use it in a BDG. You can also download the OpenAPI metadata document for the service there under API Resources / API specification.

Tutorial Setup

Before we can use the SAP Ariba service in a BDG, we need to setup the two destinations in SAP BTP.

Prerequisites:

  • SAP Integration Suite with API Management and Graph enabled
  • Access to destinations and service instances in SAP BTP cockpit

Data Destination

Open the SAP BTP Cockpit and create a new destination from scratch in the BTP subaccount where you have Graph and SAP Integration Suite. Enter the following details

  • Name: ariba-network-catalog-mgmt
  • URL: https://sandbox.api.sap.com/ariba/api/network-catalog-mgmt/v1/sandbox

Also add these two additional properties to the destination:

  • Key: Graph.destinationType with the value: REST. This declares this destination as a REST data destination to Graph.
  • Key: URL.headers.apiKey with the value: <your sandbox API key> to add your sandbox API key for authentication purposes (this only applies to this sandbox-example). You can retrieve your API key here: https://api.sap.com/settings.

data destination in BTP cockpit

Metadata Destination

Next, we need to define the metadata destination that points to a location where Graph can access the OpenAPI metadata document. This could be done in a number of ways by hosting this file in a file-server/document storage or at a custom service endpoint for example. For sake of keeping this tutorial simple we will only use SAP Integration Suite to make this file available to Graph: we will create an API artifact which returns the content of the OpenAPI metadata file and then create the metadata destination that points towards the endpoint of that API artifact. Note that this is only for the purposes of this tutorial, and not a requirement.

Hosting the OpenAPI file with an API artifact (optional, only for the tutorial)

First we create the API artifact in SAP Integration Suite. Open Integration Suite and go to Design > Integrations and APIs. Choose an existing package or create a new one. In the package click Edit and open the Artifacts tab. Now you can select Add > API in the table menu. Follow the API creation dialog and select REST API as API Type, Create as Method and then give it the following name: Ariba-Network-Catalog-OpenAPI. Open the created API and in the 'Handle Request' lane select the 'Content Modifier' step. In the bottom UI panel you will then see the Message Body tab where we can paste a constant body this API should return. Here, we will paste the JSON content of the OpenAPI specification of the service (available here). If you have other APIs in the tenant you might also want to assign a unique path for this API. To do that select the HTTPS arrow outgoing from the Start participant, and then in the bottom UI panel you can edit the 'Connection' and change the path in the 'Address' field. Here, we are using /ariba-network-catalog-openapi. Then save the API artifact and deploy it. You can check the deployment status under Monitor > Integrations and APIs > Manage Integration Content: All. When it is deployed, the OpenAPI document will be available at that endpoint. Copy the endpoint URL for later.

constant message body returns the OPenAPI spec JSON

 

unique path for this API artifact

 

monitoring view of the deployed API artifact, with the endpoint URL

To access that endpoint in a destination, we also need the authentication details. Here, we want to authenticate using OAuth client credentials that we obtain from a SAP Process Integration Runtime. For that, go to BTP Cockpit and under Services > Instances and Subscriptions you can find it or create a new one. Then create a Service Key for that instance. We now have a set of client credentials we need for authentication: namely the clientid, clientsecret and tokenurl.

process integration runtime with a service key in BTP cockpit 

Creating the Destination

Now we can create the Metadata destination. Enter the following details:

  • Name: ariba-network-catalog-mgmt-openapi
  • URL: the API artifact endpoint URL from above
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials
  • Client ID: clientid from above
  • Client Secret: clientsecret from above
  • Token Service URL: tokenurl from above

We will also annotate this destination with additional properties, to tell Graph that this is the metadata destination for the previously created ariba-network-catalog-mgmt destination:

  • Key: Graph.destinationType, with a value of OpenAPI
  • Key: Graph.metadataFor, with a value of ariba-network-catalog-mgmt

metadata destination

Now the destination setup is complete and we can create a BDG.

Creating the BDG with REST data sources

With the data destination and the metadata destination created, we can now continue to create a BDG with the REST service. The process does not differ much in this case. In Integration Suite under Design > Graph, create a new Business Data Graph with the ID rest-bdg. In the list of destinations, you can now see an ariba-network-catalog-mgmt entry with the type REST. The info icon shows you more details, for example that Graph has identified which metadata destination belongs to this entry. Just select the entry and continue. When the dialog is finished and we see a preview of the BDG details, we can also change the namespace of the data source from my.custom to my.ariba (this is optional). Continue by activating the BDG.

data source selection when creating a new BDG

 

editing the namespace of a data source

 

overview of the activated BDG

Making Queries against the BDG

With the BDG activated, we can now inspect the mirrored operations. Open the BDG in Developer Hub (there is a link on the overview tab of the BDG). You will see the following operations:

  • GET products (mirrored from GET /products)
  • GET products_ (mirrored from GET /products/{productid})
  • POST products__delete (mirrored from DELETE /products/{productid})
  • POST products__patch (mirrored from PATCH /products/{productid})
  • POST products_post (mirrored from POST /products)

The productid path parameter here is either transformed into an unbound function path parameter, or an unbound action body parameter in this example. This illustrates the transformation that Graph makes of the mirrored operations into valid OData operations as mentioned earlier. In the try out tab we can see all the parameters of the operation and also give it a go.

Note: Graph treats all parameters of mirrored operations as required at this time. However, you can set the value to null.

 
This SAP Ariba sandbox API requires an X_ARIBA_NETWORK_ID parameter. You can use the value AN02005777309 for this sandbox. When running the my.ariba/products operation, we can see that we get the response from the REST service in a valid OData format.
 
trying out the mirrored functions in Developer Hub (Graph Navigator)

Summary

In this tutorial we had a look at how REST services can be used as data sources in a business data graph. With this feature, you can integrate data from REST services alongside data from OData services into a single unified Graph API.

You can learn more about REST-support in Graph in the documentation:

  • REST services as data sources
  • Connect to your business systems: REST services

--

Florian Moritz

entry.title: **Subject: Live Session: Developing SAP Crystal Reports 2025 on the BI Platform**
entry.content:
Join us for an in-depth live session focused on developing and managing reports with the latest SAP Crystal Reports 2025 and BusinessObjects BI Platform 2025.

**Date & Time:** Wednesday, January 28, 2026, at 10:00 AM (America/New York)

**Duration:** 2 hours

**Format:** Live Online Session

**(Note: This session may be repeated quarterly based on attendee interest.)**

 

#### **Who Should Attend?**

This session is designed for customers and consultants responsible for maintaining or developing enterprise reports using SAP Crystal Reports 2025 with the on-premise BI Platform 2025.

 

#### **Why This Session is for You**

While SAP Analytics Cloud is the recommended solution for new analytics projects, SAP Crystal Reports remains a cornerstone for enterprise reporting at thousands of companies. SAP's commitment to the BusinessObjects BI platform includes mainstream maintenance until at least the end of 2031, securing your investment for the long term.

 

This session will empower you to maximize the value of your existing infrastructure and leverage the latest innovations.

 

#### **Agenda: What You Will Learn**

This two-hour session will focus on three key areas:

  1.   **Developing Reports:** A step-by-step guide to building a new report from scratch in Crystal Reports 2025.
  2.   **Managing Reports:** Best practices for publishing, scheduling, and securing your reports within the SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform 2025.
  3.   **Optimizing Performance:** Techniques to build efficient reports and troubleshoot performance bottlenecks within the BI Platform.

 

#### **Unable to Attend?**

For those who cannot make the live session, we recommend these three free online courses to get you started:

  • Creating a Simple Report in SAP Crystal Reports - 3 Hours
  • Enhancing an Existing Report in SAP Crystal Reports - 2 Hours
  • Exploring Advanced Reporting Strategies in SAP Crystal Reports - 3 Hours

 

#### **Call to Action**

**Ready to master Crystal Reports 2025?**

**[REGISTER HERE]**

Developing reports in SAP Crystal Reports 2025

---

entry.title: Re: SAP BTP - APIM - Demystified: Designing a Single API Proxy with Dynamic Routing for Multiple Tar
entry.content:
@Abuislam1 

Yes is also possible via query or header you just need to change the routing parameters.

Query:

variable: request.querystring  -  sample: Client_id=100&Receiver_ID=SAPCLNT200&Sender_ID=343132143
 
In case that you want make based on custom headers in the message you need create something like this:
 
Custom headers Postman:

 

 

Java Script to capture the custom headers based on the name, without it you don't have visibility of the variable in runtime:
 

 

//Custom Headers
function getcustomheaders(){
    var businessUnit = context.getVariable("request.header.X-Business-Unit");
    var sourceSystem = context.getVariable("request.header.X-Source-System");
    context.setVariable("custom.business_unit", businessUnit);
    context.setVariable("custom.source_system", sourceSystem);
}

 

Really no sure if it's really valid routing based on the header but anyway the solution is in place.

entry.title: Accounting Evolves, Digital Transforms. With IPSAS.
entry.content:
Why IPSAS and Digital Transformation Matter for Public Sector

Public sector organizations worldwide face a dual challenge: adopting International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS) while driving digital transformation. This isn‚Äôt just about technology‚Äîit‚Äôs about teamwork, governance, and collaboration.

IPSAS adoption ensures transparency and accountability in financial reporting. Digital transformation, powered by platforms like SAP Business Suite, accelerates this process by automating workflows, enabling real-time insights, and embedding AI-driven intelligence.

IPSAS Meets the Digital Era
The December 2025 Brussels event, Where IPSAS Meets Digital Transformation, brought together leaders from EU institutions, EY, SAP, and ServiceNow to explore how digital technologies are reshaping public‚Äësector financial management. Speakers highlighted that European institutions are operating in an increasingly volatile landscape, characterized by geopolitical uncertainty, legacy systems, and rising regulatory complexity. IPSAS continues to act as the backbone of trustworthy public reporting, but the message was clear: only by coupling IPSAS with modern digital tools‚ÄîAI‚Äëenabled ERP, integrated risk platforms, and automated workflows‚Äîcan institutions meet the transparency and efficiency demands of tomorrow.

SUMMA: A Once‚Äëin‚Äëa‚ÄëGeneration Transformation
A good intro on modernization of an accounting platform was  the European Commission‚Äôs SUMMA program, its next‚Äëgeneration financial management platform set to replace ABAC. SUMMA aims to create standardized, automated, and analytics‚Äëready processes across budgeting, accounting, treasury, and reporting. Presenters emphasized the enormous scale: 450,000 beneficiaries, over 2.5 million payments per year, and more than 13,000 users. The transition faces challenges such as aligning diverse processes with standard solutions, overcoming resistance to change, and integrating dozens of corporate and local systems. Yet with a disciplined ‚Äúgreenfield‚Äù approach, iterative pilots, strong governance, and SAP partnership, SUMMA is positioned to become the digital heart of EU financial operations.

Innovation Through AI, Integrated Toolchains, and Process Excellence
Jointly with  EY we showcased how an integrated digital toolchain‚ÄîSAP Business Suite with embedded AI, SAP Signavio for process intelligence, and WalkMe for adoption‚Äîcan modernize IPSAS‚Äëaligned financial processes. Demonstrations highlighted low‚Äëtouch accounting, AI‚Äëassisted controls, automated budget insights, and end‚Äëto‚Äëend process standardization. Signavio enables IPSAS‚Äëcompliant workflows with embedded checkpoints, while WalkMe accelerates user adoption through in‚Äëapp guidance and automation. Together, these tools strengthen data accuracy, improve compliance, and support continuous transformation‚Äîcritical pillars as public‚Äësector finance embraces AI and new digital operating models.
See below the new reference content in LeanIX for Public Sector transformation projects:

What is IPSAS 47 & 48? New Standards, New Challenges
The closing sessions addressed the upcoming IPSAS 47 (Revenue) and IPSAS 48 (Transfer Expenses), which take effect in January 2026 and introduce more nuanced accounting models built around the concept of ‚Äúbinding arrangements.‚Äù Speakers examined practical challenges such as identifying enforceable rights and obligations, defining compliance obligations, assessing transfer rights, and managing new reporting requirements. While these standards increase complexity, they also strengthen accountability, aligning public‚Äësector reporting more closely with economic reality. Panelists agreed: effective implementation will require robust governance, high‚Äëquality data, strong systems alignment, and significant education for both preparers and stakeholders.

The Road Ahead
Digital transformation and IPSAS adoption are not isolated initiatives‚Äîthey are strategic imperatives for modern governance. With SAP‚Äôs integrated solutions and AI-driven innovation, governments can achieve transparency, efficiency, and sustainability.

entry.title: Inside the GCID AI Hackathon: A Global Contest where AI Initiatives came to life.
entry.content:
A journey that came to life on stage

The Hackathon had place in December 10 during a hybrid event hosted by Matheus Souza, AI Incubation Head, in Sofia. Where a global audience came together both in person and online. And more than 170 participants tuned in as the 11 finalist teams presented their work during the qualifying round and later to the finals.

Each team stepped on stage with a short, high-impact pitch supported by a live demo. In just 7 minutes, they told the story behind their solutions, showing how AI can address concrete technical and business challenges when creativity, and clear communication come together. From this round, three teams stood out and advanced to the final.

The final round opened with motivating messages from Ozren Kopajtic, GCID Head, Kiril Krantev representing the GCID T&I Cloud Operations, and Ricardo Silva GCID Business Delivery Excellence Head. Then the atmosphere was further energized by an inspiring message from Thomas Saueressig, and the executive jury: Radoslav Nikolov, Niraj Singh, Boris Maeck, Henning Heitk√∂tter, and Ricardo Silva. Who encouraged teams to continue pushing their ideas.

Awarding outstanding ideas and execution

Throughout the hackathon, one message became clear: AI has the potential to reshape how we operate, decide, and scale across the organization. The event came an end with Radoslav, Ricardo and Matheus, announcing and celebrating the teams whose solutions stood out for their originality, technical strength, and real-world applicability:

  • First place:" AI-Powered AWX Analyser & Hammer Helper" by Barath Ramachandran, Suresh Kumar Sekar, and team
  • Second place: "Smart Data Center" by Geghard Bedrosian, Philipp Matthes, and team
  • Third place: "AI for Smarter Observability Hygiene" by Mario Romero, Duc Nguyen, and team

What‚Äôs next for the hackathon journey

Rather than an ending, this first edition marked the beginning of something bigger. Announced at the end of the event, the hosting city for this year's edition of the GCID AI Hackathon will take is Budapest. There the community is set to continue growing and creating even more space for experimentation and innovation.

The excitement is already building for what the next edition will bring, and we can't wait for it to begin. See you there?

entry.title: Re: SAP SuccessFactors Custom Cards is not Retaining Image

entry.title: Re: PERSONAS 3.0 : How to display Google Maps
entry.content:
For adding Google Maps to your flavor, you can use an HTML Viewer control. However, you will need your own API key for embedding. Refer to The Maps Embed API overview  |  Google for Developers for more details.

There are other map provides you could use, for example OpenStreetMap. For seamless embedding, it also requires the use of their geocoding API, but for simple embedding of a map window, you could use the https://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/ui/search.html?q= URL of your HTML Viewer and add your target address, separated with the plus sign. For example, https://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/ui/search.html?q=350+Fifth+Avenue+New+York+NY shows the location of the Empire State Building.
At least this works for USA addresses, but it may not work as well for other locations.

entry.title: Native Sparkplug B Support in SAP Integration Suite using the Advantco MQTT Adapter.
entry.content:
Deep Dive: Native Sparkplug B Support in SAP Integration Suite using the Advantco MQTT Adapter

1. Why Sparkplug Matters in Enterprise SAP Integrations
While MQTT is widely adopted in Industrial IoT, it is intentionally minimal. MQTT defines transport mechanics, but it does not define:
- How device identity should be modeled
- How telemetry should be structured
- How lifecycle or state should be communicated
- How downstream systems should interpret metrics consistently
Sparkplug B addresses these gaps by defining a strict topic namespace, lifecycle messages (birth/death), and a Protobuf-based payload model.
This transforms MQTT from a ‚Äúfire-and-forget‚Äù transport into a state-aware, enterprise-ready data backbone.
For SAP landscapes, this distinction is critical. SAP systems depend on deterministic structures, governed master data, and lifecycle awareness.
Sparkplug provides exactly those guarantees at the edge.

2. What Makes the Advantco MQTT Adapter Sparkplug-Native
Most MQTT integrations in SAP Integration Suite require custom Java or external decoding services to handle Sparkplug payloads.
The Advantco MQTT Adapter embeds Sparkplug B semantics directly into the adapter runtime.
Native capabilities include:
- Direct subscription to Sparkplug topic namespaces
- Automatic decoding of Sparkplug Protobuf payloads into JSON
- Built-in Sparkplug B XML schemas
- Automatic Protobuf encoding on publish
- Symmetric support for consume and publish flows
This shifts Sparkplug from a ‚Äúspecial case‚Äù to a first-class integration pattern.

3. Sparkplug Topic Semantics and iFlow Design
Sparkplug topics follow a deterministic structure:
namespace/group_id/message_type/edge_node_id/[device_id]

In Cloud Integration, the topic itself becomes an integration key.
The Advantco MQTT adapter preserves the full topic string, allowing iFlows to:
- Route by message_type (DBIRTH vs DDATA)
- Resolve asset identity using group/edge/device
- Enforce governance rules per site or production line

Recommended design:
- Separate iFlows for lifecycle (BIRTH/DEATH) and telemetry (DATA)
- Treat BIRTH messages as master data refresh events
- Treat DEATH messages as operational exceptions

4. Consuming Sparkplug Messages: Adapter-Level Processing
When configured as a consumer, the Advantco MQTT adapter:
- Subscribes using Sparkplug-compliant topics
- Supports wildcards (+, #) and multiple topic filters
- Receives Protobuf payloads directly from the broker
- Converts payloads into structured JSON automatically

The decoded JSON includes:
- Sequence numbers (seq)
- Metric lists with datatype awareness
- Timestamps per metric
This allows downstream CPI steps to focus purely on business logic.

Figure 1: Advantco MQTT Sender Adapter configuration showing Sparkplug B topic subscriptions and Sparkplug B (Eclipse Tahu) data format selection.

5. Payload Canonicalization and Mapping Strategy

Once Sparkplug payloads are decoded by the adapter, they can be processed in either JSON or XML format, depending on downstream integration requirements.
While JSON is often preferred for modern APIs, many SAP Integration Suite scenarios still rely on XML-based routing, XPath expressions, and message mappings.
To support this, the Advantco MQTT Adapter provides built-in Sparkplug content conversion capabilities.

By enabling content conversion in the Advanced tab of the adapter and selecting the Sparkplug B XML Schema, Sparkplug payloads can be converted between XML and JSON formats without custom Groovy scripts or Java mappings.

This ensures that:
- Sparkplug semantics remain enforced at the adapter level
- Integration logic works with a stable, schema-driven payload
- Canonicalization happens before business mapping

Figure 2: Advantco MQTT Adapter ‚Äì Content Conversion configuration using the Sparkplug B XML schema (XML ‚Üí JSON)

6. Publishing Sparkplug Commands from SAP
Sparkplug defines NCMD and DCMD message types for control and actuation.

The Advantco MQTT adapter supports publishing Sparkplug messages by:
- Accepting JSON or XML payloads
- Enforcing Sparkplug schema compliance
- Automatically encoding payloads into Protobuf
Exact topic names must be specified, ensuring deterministic command routing.
This allows SAP to safely participate in closed-loop control scenarios.

7. Operational Considerations and Best Practices
Key operational guidance:
- Persist Sparkplug birth sequence numbers to detect restarts
- Use DEATH messages to trigger SAP alerts or incidents
- Avoid pushing raw high-frequency telemetry directly into SAP
- Apply thresholds and aggregation inside CPI or downstream services
Sparkplug enables state-aware integration, but architectural discipline is still required.

8. Reference Architecture
Edge Devices ‚Üí Sparkplug Gateway ‚Üí MQTT Broker ‚Üí SAP Integration Suite
- Advantco MQTT Adapter handles Sparkplug semantics
- Cloud Integration performs routing, mapping, and governance
- SAP systems consume normalized business events
This architecture cleanly separates OT concerns from IT governance.

9. Why This Pattern Scales
By combining Sparkplug B with SAP Integration Suite:
- OT systems gain enterprise visibility
- SAP avoids tight coupling to device protocols
- Integration logic remains deterministic and auditable
- Future analytics and AI layers can be added without rework
Sparkplug becomes the contract, CPI becomes the orchestrator.

10. Conclusion
The Advantco MQTT Adapter elevates Sparkplug B from a protocol detail to a core SAP integration capability.
By handling Protobuf encoding, lifecycle semantics, and schema conversion natively, it allows SAP Integration Suite to function as a true Industrial IoT integration hub.
This enables scalable, governed, and future-proof OT-to-IT integration architectures on SAP BTP.

11. Sources
- https://mqtt.org/
- https://sparkplug.eclipse.org/specification/
- https://www.advantco.com/sap-integration-adapters/sap-mqtt-integration

entry.title: Setting Up PostgreSQL for SAP BTP Development: A Practical Guide
entry.content:
Setting Up PostgreSQL for SAP BTP Development: A Practical Guide

Part 1 of a series ‚Äî next up: implementing OAuth with XSUAA and PostgreSQL

Not every BTP application needs HANA Cloud. PostgreSQL on SAP BTP is a managed database service running on hyperscaler infrastructure. Credentials arrive via VCAP_SERVICES in Cloud Foundry or Kubernetes secrets in Kyma.

When Should You Choose PostgreSQL Over HANA Cloud?

Need analytics or calculation views? ‚Üí HANA Cloud
Need MTX support? ‚Üí HANA Cloud


Everything else? ‚Üí PostgreSQL

That's really it. If you're not using HANA-specific features, you're paying premium prices for a standard relational database. PostgreSQL handles CRUD just as well at a fraction of the cost.

Provisioning PostgreSQL on SAP BTP

Prerequisites: Setting Up Entitlements

Before you can create a PostgreSQL instance, your subaccount needs the right entitlements. For trial account it's set up by default.

Method 1: Creating via BTP Cockpit (UI)

This approach works well when you're getting started or creating a one-off instance.

Step 1: Navigate to your Cloud Foundry Space

  • BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Subaccount ‚Üí Cloud Foundry ‚Üí Spaces ‚Üí [Your Space]

Step 2: Open the Service Marketplace

  • Click Services in the left menu ‚Üí Service Marketplace

Step 3: Find PostgreSQL

  • Search for "PostgreSQL" or look for "PostgreSQL, hyperscaler option"
  • Click on the tile

Step 4: Create a new instance

  • Click the Create button

Step 5: Name your instance psql-dev and click Create

The provisioning takes 5-15 minutes.

Method 2: Creating via CF CLI

cf login -a https://api.cf.eu10.hana.ondemand.com
cf target -o my-organization -s my-space

# Create the service instance
cf create-service postgresql-db free psql-dev

# Monitor the creation progress
cf service psql-dev

The cf service command will show status like "create in progress" initially, then "create succeeded" when ready.

Getting Your Database Credentials

Once your instance is created, you need credentials to connect. There are two approaches depending on your use case.

For Applications: Service Binding

If you're deploying an application to Cloud Foundry, the standard approach is binding:

# Bind the service to your app
cf bind-service my-application psql-dev

# Restage to pick up the new binding
cf restage my-application

After binding, your application receives credentials via the VCAP_SERVICES environment variable. Here's what that looks like (simplified):

{
  "postgresql-db": [{
    "credentials": {
      "hostname": "postgres-abc123.database.sap.hana.ondemand.com",
      "port": "5432",
      "dbname": "postgres",
      "username": "user_xyz",
      "password": "generated-secure-password",
      "uri": "postgres://user_xyz:password@hostname:5432/postgres?sslmode=verify-full",
      "sslcert": "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----\n...",
      "sslrootcert": "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----\n..."
    }
  }]
}

Important: Notice the SSL certificates. BTP PostgreSQL requires SSL connections ‚Äî this isn't optional.

For Local Development

BTP PostgreSQL isn't publicly accessible from your laptop. For local development, just run PostgreSQL locally via Docker ‚Äî it's faster anyway.

Option 1: Local PostgreSQL via Docker

For CAP apps, use the pg.yaml shown in the CAP section below with cds watch --profile pg. For non-CAP apps, the same Docker setup works ‚Äî just connect to localhost:5432 with user/password postgres.

Option 2: Deploy pgAdmin on BTP

Need to browse your BTP database with a GUI? Deploy pgAdmin directly on Cloud Foundry ‚Äî it runs inside the network and connects without tunneling.

manifest.yml:

applications:
- name: pgadmin-web
  memory: 1G
  disk_quota: 1G
  health-check-type: process
  docker:
    image: dpage/pgadmin4:latest
  random-route: true
  env:
    PGADMIN_DEFAULT_EMAIL: admin@admin.com
    PGADMIN_DEFAULT_PASSWORD: admin123
cf push

Open the route URL from the output, login with the credentials above, and add your server using the hostname/port/username/password from your service key.

Connecting from Different Application Types

Now for the practical part ‚Äî actually connecting your code to the database. I'll cover the major scenarios.

Scenario 1: CAP Application (Node.js)

The @cap-js/postgres package provides official PostgreSQL support.

Setup:

cds add postgres

Local development with Docker:

# pg.yaml
services:
  db:
    image: postgres:alpine
    environment: { POSTGRES_PASSWORD: postgres }
    ports: ['5432:5432']
docker compose -f pg.yaml up -d
cds watch --profile pg

The @cap-js/postgres package comes with default credentials under profile [pg] that match the Docker defaults ‚Äî no configuration needed.

Scenario 2: Plain Node.js Application (Express, Fastify, etc.)

Here's where things get interesting for non-CAP developers. You can use PostgreSQL with any Node.js framework using the standard pg package.

Installation:

npm install pg @sap/xsenv

Connection setup:

// db.js - Database connection module
const { Pool } = require('pg');
const xsenv = require('@sap/xsenv');

// Load environment (works both locally with default-env.json and on CF)
xsenv.loadEnv();

// Get PostgreSQL credentials from VCAP_SERVICES
const pgCredentials = xsenv.getServices({ 
  postgres: { label: 'postgresql-db' } 
}).postgres;

// Create connection pool with SSL configuration
const pool = new Pool({
  host: pgCredentials.hostname,
  port: parseInt(pgCredentials.port, 10),
  database: pgCredentials.dbname,
  user: pgCredentials.username,
  password: pgCredentials.password,
});

// Test the connection on startup
pool.query('SELECT NOW()')
  .then(() => console.log('‚úÖ PostgreSQL connected'))
  .catch(err => console.error('‚ùå PostgreSQL connection failed:', err));

module.exports = pool;

Using it in your routes:

// routes/users.js
const express = require('express');
const pool = require('../db');
const router = express.Router();

router.get('/users', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const result = await pool.query('SELECT id, name, email FROM users');
    res.json(result.rows);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('Query error:', err);
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Database error' });
  }
});

router.post('/users', async (req, res) => {
  const { name, email } = req.body;
  try {
    const result = await pool.query(
      'INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES ($1, $2) RETURNING *',
      [name, email]
    );
    res.status(201).json(result.rows[0]);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('Insert error:', err);
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Database error' });
  }
});

module.exports = router;

What's Next: Building OAuth Authentication with XSUAA

Now that you have PostgreSQL running on BTP, we're ready to build something practical.

In the next article, we'll implement OAuth 2.0 authentication using XSUAA and PostgreSQL ‚Äî without relying on the CAP framework.

See you in Part 2!

Resources

  • CAP: Using PostgreSQL
  • PostgreSQL on SAP BTP - Hyperscaler Option
  • @cap-js/postgres package

entry.title: Re: ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development
entry.content:
Hi @gerardo_martingozalo,

 ABAP_CLEAN_CORE_DEVELOPMENT check variant should be used for the development in the newer S/4HANA >=2022 systems, for the older systems (like in your landscape) some (or many, depends on the release) checks of this variant can be not suitable like this CDS check, where you get the error.

If you only want to use the new clean core checks (category "Clean core") as described in this blog, then please create a new ATC check variant and include only the clean core checks. See the blog https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/how-to-create-and-use-your-own-atc-check-variant-in-abap-development-tools/ba-p/13512135 .Provide also the source for released SAP APIs in this variant: you need to provide the value of the releasedAPIDataSource check parameter like this (e.g. using latest version of the released SAP APIs for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) like described in the blog:

Please let me know if you have any additional questions.

Kind regards,
Olga.

entry.title: Forms Service by Adobe (BTP): Persistent "No client with requested id" Error after Configuration
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am seeking assistance with a persistent authentication issue while setting up SAP Forms Service by Adobe in the BTP Cloud Foundry environment.

Despite following the standard setup documentation, I am unable to access the Template Store UI. I consistently receive the following error: No client with requested id: sb-ads-xsappname!b65488

What I have configured so far:

  1. Entitlements: Added "Forms Service by Adobe" and "Forms Service by Adobe API" (free plans).

  2. Subscription: Successfully subscribed to "Forms Service by Adobe" (default plan).

  3. Instance: Created a service instance for "Forms Service by Adobe API" in my space.

  4. Role Collections: Created and assigned a Role Collection containing ADSAdmin and TemplateStoreAdmin.

  5. Direct Access: I have tried accessing the UI via the "Go to Application" link and via the direct URL found in the destination configuration.

Steps taken to resolve the issue (but failed):

  • Verified that the Application Identifier in the Role Collection matches the subscription.

  • Unsubscribed and re-subscribed to force a new OAuth registration.

  • Cleared browser cache and used Incognito/Guest modes.

  • Waited for propagation (over 30 minutes).

It seems the XSUAA service is still looking for a specific client ID (!b65488) that perhaps isn't being correctly mapped or registered in the Trust Configuration.

System Details:

  • Environment: Cloud Foundry

  • Region: US10

  • Identity Provider: Default and Custom

Has anyone encountered this specific mismatch before? Is there a way to force a refresh of the OAuth2 clients in the subaccount, or is this a backend issue that requires an SAP Support ticket?

Thank you for your help!

entry.title: Re: Mass update journal entry G/L item field ‚ÄúReference 1‚Äù
entry.content:
There is no standard app to mass change this field for posted G/L items. The supported option is the SOAP API ‚ÄúJournal Entry ‚Äì Change (Asynchronous)‚Äù (JournalEntryBulkChangeRequest_In), which allows bulk changes of journal entry header/item data for documents with entry views. If the field is not changeable, the API rejects the request (for example: ‚Äúfield is not open for input‚Äù). Processing can be monitored via AIF / Message Dashboard.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/c3833c31e7724a79b23e4273290f3e2e.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

entry.title: Join Our Live Session: SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 ‚Äì Generative AI & Machine Learning
entry.content:
On behalf of the SAP Product learning team, I am thrilled to invite you to an exciting live session where we‚Äôll dive deep into the latest Generative AI and Machine Learning capabilities in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.

Session Details

entry.title: Re: Personas SP20 - after upgrade screen display inconsis...
entry.content: Background: We are on Personas 3.0 SP18, Personas are used to enhance EWM_MOBGUI screens for /SCWM/RFUI application. We use only 1 flavor assigned through security role and FlavorID in /PERSONAS/ADMIN is matching with FlavorID on this displayed screen (we use inspect element). We have 2 scripts a) to change background color of an active field b) play audio beeps and the scripts are firing good. Application has been deployed 3 warehouses and are working as expected in DEV, QA and Prod environment. Additional info: /SCWM/RFUI screen fields are configurable, meaning, the number of fields displayed on the screen (mobile) can/are controlled by configuration. Symptoms: We were building 4th Warehouse. Already existing flavor was updated with new application screens for 4th Warehouse. Performance was bad during test, so DEV was upgraded to SP19 and then to SP20, while QA is in SP19. Some of the application screens on display doesnt adapt flavor, raw screen is displayed on load, however, with superuser role, click P, select original screen and then again select the created flavor then displays the screen correctly. Also script are not triggering any more. Question: Some application screen share same screen program name and screen number, but the 4th Warehouse, have more fields to display. How does Personas determine positions for this new fields? or if some fields were removed, how does Personas handle the removed/suppressed fields? Also both the scripts are not triggering for the 4th Warehouse(triggers for other 3 warehouses. There are NO failures noticed in security trace. Is it possible Personas is storing organizational elements (like Plant number, Warehouse number etc)?

entry.title: 2602 Early Release Series for SAP Ariba and SAP Business Network releases
entry.content:
Sign up now for the 2602 Early Release Series

Follow this blog to receive notification of new series as soon as registration opens.

SAP strives to equip our customers and partners with valuable release readiness resources for each SAP Ariba and SAP Business Network quarterly release.

 

Early Release Series

The Early Release Series webcasts cover features planned for the upcoming SAP Ariba and SAP Business Network quarterly release.  This platform, available to customers and partners, has a clear mission: deliver an interactive forum to engage with SAP product experts providing simple, direct answers to your most pressing questions.  There is a different session for each product area with content tailored for the specific audience:

  • Supplier Management & Risk
  • Procure to Pay
  • Source to Contract
  • Business Network

If you want to learn more and actively engage with SAP subject matter experts, we encourage you to participate in these informative sessions.  Register now!

Quarterly Release Communications

Notice of upcoming quarterly releases will be communicated to Buyer customers three weeks prior to the release date.  Suppliers receive notice two weeks prior.  Releases are communicated via email notification (look for subject line starting with: Advance Release Notice).

Anyone from your organization that has chosen to subscribe to product notifications will receive these announcements. 

The release calendar for SAP Business Network  and release calendar SAP Ariba Applications identify release timing several quarters in advance.

Where to find out more details?

On demand replays of webcasts from completed quarterly releases can be consumed from Release Readiness Resources: Webcast Archive Page

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì UX Adoption accelerators updated for AI, Clean Core, and S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Planning to grow your SAP Fiori usage in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or SAP S/4HANA (on-premise)?

Need to shift your users from SAP GUI to SAP Fiori to SAP Joule & SAP Business AI ?

Want to bring the latest Clean Core techniques to your teams? 

Good news!  

The SAP Activate roadmap UX Adoption accelerators have now been updated for:

  • SAP S/4HANA 2025 latest launchpad features, apps, and resources
  • SAP Business AI and Joule use cases
  • SAP Build Work Zone options including SAP Mobile Start
  • Clean Core extension options and tools

You will also find helpful advice on:

  • Using SAP Joule for Consultants when you select and extend apps
  • Getting the most from the new list view of SAP Fiori apps reference library
  • Capturing your UX scope and requirements with SAP‚Äôs Integrated Tool Chain ‚Äì SAP LeanIX, SAP Signavio Process Manager, SAP Cloud ALM, and SAP WalkMe
  • Enabling your technical teams for your UX journey

You can find the accelerators by selecting the tag User Experience in your preferred SAP Activate roadmap viewer at https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer. You will find them in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP Cloud ERP Private roadmaps for New Installation, System Conversion, Selective Data Transition, and Upgrades. 

Hint: Most advice in the accelerators is also relevant to customers using SAP S/4HANA on-premise.  For use of SAP Business AI in SAP S/4HANA on-premise refer to SAP Note 3632703 - Enabling Joule for On-Premise systems

In SAP Activate, you can also search for accelerators using keyword UX Adoption or try Joule in SAP Activate. 

Example screenshot: Using the tag User Experience in the SAP Cloud ERP Private - System Conversion roadmap to find UX Adoption accelerators. Links to the accelerators are highlighted.

In this blog post you will find:

  • What‚Äôs New/Changed highlights
  • Where to find the accelerators ‚Äì step by step
  • FAQ

What‚Äôs New/Changed Highlights

All updated accelerators are marked as version December 2025.

Example screenshot: Title slide of the workshop template UX Adoption: Establish the Business Value of UX . The version December 2025 is highlighted and appears below the title.

All 6 of the UX Adoption Workshop Templates have been updated.  The UX Adoption workshops encourage an iterative approach to UX Adoption so you can manage the pace of change.

  • All workshop templates are provided in ready-to-use Microsoft Powerpoint PPTX format.
  • All workshop templates now include a Content Summary slide so you don‚Äôt miss out on any of the good stuff in the Additional Resources section.

Example screenshot:  Content Summary slide of the workshop template UX Adoption: Establish the Business Value of UX .  Highlighted are in the Additional Resources are: Major points and demonstration hints; Going beyond SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition; Persona templates for pre-/post- workshop homework; UX Value Goals Deeper Dive slides with AI-assisted examples;  Information for the Technical Team.

 

Summary of Workshop Templates - purpose and major changes:

  • Establish the Business Value of UX ‚Äì Introduce SAP Fiori to your business stakeholders and technical teams. Links to the latest demo videos (including free SAP Learning videos) are included so you can demo the latest SAP Fiori user experience like a pro!  You will also find tips to get your technical team started on supporting your UX adoption journey. 

 

  • UX Strategy and Guiding Principles ‚Äì Grow awareness of launchpad features that apply across most apps and processes, including SAP Joule and SAP Mobile Start.  Quickly build consensus on which features to use now/next/later.  Now extended with latest available features such as SAP Joule, the Unified Navigation Bar, Manage News app, collaboration using Microsoft Teams, and App Inspector for easy troubleshooting.

 

  • Scope the Future ‚Äì Scope and evaluate apps and features that fit with your business value goals. Now with advice on how to match SAP Business AI use cases - including Joule ‚Äì to your desired business outcomes. You will also find updated a step-by-step guide for evaluating apps in 5-10 minutes.  Get tips on using no-code/low-code upgrade-safe Clean Core key user extensions - such as Adapt UI ‚Äì to check what‚Äôs easy to change for your selected apps.  Includes Clean core references, such as SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì What is Key User Extensibility and Who are your Key Users for key users and SAP Note  3578329 - Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility for developers.

 

  • Envision the Future ‚Äì Estimate extension effort, refine your scope, and agree on business benefits to highlight to your users.  Updated for AI effort considerations.

 

  • Design your Launchpad Layout ‚Äì Make changes easy for your users to adopt.  Updated with the latest features of spaces and pages layouts.

 

  • Review Business Benefits Realization ‚Äì Measure usage, capture adoption learnings, and trigger the next iteration of UX Adoption. Now with tips on using Early Watch for usage metrics; plus, tracking process improvements with SAP Signavio Process Insights.

Other updated UX Adoption accelerators:

  • SAP User Experience Strategy Template ‚Äì Document your UX Adoption decisions made in your workshops. Capture your agreed business aims, high-level direction, architecture, phases, and progress.  You will see helpful examples and starting points. Now updated with more guidance on SAP Build Work Zone architecture options; SAP Business AI considerations and references; software accessibility (e.g. WCAG) compliance considerations; example timelines for small vs larger adoption projects; latest launchpad content and support tooling; app lifecycle and transport management; and managing security authorizations for your SAP Fiori apps.

 Hint: The User Experience Strategy Template is provided in Microsoft Word DOCX format to get you started quickly.  

  • UX Adoption: UX Value Goal App Selection Guides ‚Äì Select apps and features that match your business goals. All guides now contain SAP Business AI use cases. Guides now come with examples from the latest SAP S/4HANA 2025 apps, and launchpad features such as integration with Microsoft Teams chat/tabs/contacts; personalizing My Home dashboards with Add Card to Insights; and using the new list view in the SAP Fiori apps reference library to understand what‚Äôs available.  

The UX Value Goal App Selection guides are a set of 9 guides to help you match apps and features to your business goals. They include standard and custom-built options for each value goal. 

  • Be more MOBILE ‚Äì do more on more device types (tablets, phones, wearables, etc.)
  • GUIDE me better ‚Äì help me navigate my day
  • COLLABORATE better ‚Äì support working across onshore/offshore teams, for example using Microsoft Teams Integration.
  • RESPOND faster ‚Äì use Joule skills to speed up simple tasks, get fast info from search
  • REACT faster ‚Äì get notified of business situations early
  • Be more PROACTIVE ‚Äì use analytics and predictive models to trigger action
  • Be more AUTOMATED ‚Äì use Joule agents to speed up complex tasks
  • Be more ADAPTABLE ‚Äì make the most of Clean Core techniques to adapt to changing business needs

Hint: The UX Value Goal App Selection Guides are provide as a zipped file of 9 short PDFs. 

And finally:

  • Quick Guide for Fit Evaluation ‚Äì Find the easy ways to adjust apps and features to your business needs. Shift your business stakeholder (and project team) mindsets towards: using AI every day;  working well with SAP Fiori; and transitioning at your pace from SAP GUI.  Now with improved advice based on recent customer project experiences and including SAP Business AI. 

Hint: The Quick Guide for Fit Evaluation is provided as a PDF.

 

Where to find the UX Adoption Accelerators ‚Äì Step by Step

You will find the accelerators referenced in several of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition roadmaps.  

Find all the roadmaps in SAP for Me in the SAP Activate Roadmap Viewer at: https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer

Select Explore All Roadmaps to find and mark your favourites.

Example: SAP Activate Road Map Viewer page showing the Explore All Road Maps button. Favorite roadmaps are shown for SAP Activate SAP Cloud ERP  Private.

 

The SAP Activate roadmaps for SAP Cloud ERP Private (i.e. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition ) contain many UX Adoption accelerators and content tasks.

Select the tag User Experience to find the UX Adoption accelerators.

Example screenshot showing the Accelerators tab in the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - System Conversion roadmap. The tag User Experience is selected in the left-hand pane - and includes a count of the accelerators found. In the right pane the accelerators are listed by Activate phase.

 

The accelerators are shown by phase. Simply select the links to download the accelerators you want to use.

Example screenshot highlighting the links to the accelerators in the Accelerators tab of the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - System Conversion road map.

You can also search across SAP Activate to find accelerators using SAP Joule. You can get quick information on related tasks, and AI-powered insights on making the most of these accelerators.

Example screenshot of showing using the SAP Activate search with keyword ux adoption.  AI-Powered Insights are shown for the selected roadmap giving quick guidance on how to use the accelerators, followed by the Search Results with links to accelerators.

 

FAQ

Do I have to wait for our next project to get value out of the accelerators?

No. You can use the content whenever you need to build awareness, encourage further adoption, and plan next steps.

Do I have to be using SAP Activate methodology to use these accelerators?

No. 

How you run your project is up to you and your partner.  Some SAP partners have their own methodology based on SAP Activate. 

Some customers use simple mini-sprints to grow adoption - you can example of a mini-sprint plan in the SAP User Experience Strategy Template. 

However you run your project, these accelerators are provided to help you confidently introduce User Experience, collaboratively make UX adoption decisions with your business stakeholders, and successfully bring a new way of working to your business users.

Do I have to run a workshop to use the templates?

No. For example:

  • You can select slides and demo videos from Establish the Business Value of UX to explain SAP Fiori to your long-term SAP GUI users.
  • You can refer to the App Selection Guide Be more MOBILE to find what apps make sense to use on smaller devices
  • You can refer to the App Selection Guide Be more AUTOMATED to understand how to find available SAP Joule Agents and what you need to create custom-built Joule Agents.

Can I get AI to help me select apps?

Yes!

In the UX Adoption: Scope the Future Workshop Template you will find some brief examples of using SAP Joule for Consultants to get advice. For example, ‚Äúis there a Fiori app for <this task> in SAP S/4HANA <your release‚Äù.

 

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

You‚Äôll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG and Customer Care team.

entry.title: Re: Workzone hide card dynamically
entry.content:
Hi,

Maybe you can try to implement conditional rendering that completely removes the card from the DOM when no news is available. This is a sample code from Joule.

// Card Controller - Component Card Implementation
sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/integration/Extension"
], function (Extension) {
    "use strict";

    var NewsCardExtension = Extension.extend("custom.news.NewsCardExtension");

    NewsCardExtension.prototype.init = function () {
        Extension.prototype.init.apply(this, arguments);
        this.checkNewsAvailability();
    };

    NewsCardExtension.prototype.checkNewsAvailability = function () {
        // Fetch news data
        this.getNewsData().then(function(newsData) {
            if (!newsData || newsData.length === 0) {
                // Remove card completely from DOM
                this.hideCardCompletely();
            } else {
                // Render card with news content
                this.renderNewsCard(newsData);
            }
        }.bind(this));
    };

    NewsCardExtension.prototype.hideCardCompletely = function () {
        var oCard = this.getCard();
        var oCardDomRef = oCard.getDomRef();
        if (oCardDomRef && oCardDomRef.parentNode) {
            oCardDomRef.parentNode.removeChild(oCardDomRef);
        }
    };

    return NewsCardExtension;
});

 Best Regards,

Aqua

entry.content:

If you use the functions mentioned above (sorting with highest/lowest), the sequence in which the fields are sorted is relevant.

 

If you enter something in this column (values from 1 to 99), then the fields are sorted in the sequence from 1 to 99. If you do not enter anything in this column, the fields are then sorted according to their occurrence in the table (occurrence could be Date, Document#, etc.).    "

entry.title: Re: Dump CX_SY_REF_IS_INITIAL in CREATE_FS_TOOLBAR of CL_SALV_GUI_SLIS_FACTORY in SE84
entry.content:
This is a known SAP standard bug in ABAP 7.58 SP01.
The short dump CX_SY_REF_IS_INITIAL in CREATE_FS_TOOLBAR of CL_SALV_GUI_SLIS_FACTORY (triggered from SE84) is not a custom issue.

SAP has confirmed and fixed it via correction notes.

Correct fix sequence:

  • SAP Note 3433027 ‚Äì ALV: HS Grid/List and Functions Toolbar ‚Äì Correction Package

  • SAP Note 3433207 ‚Äì Technical correction (auto‚Äëinstalls dependencies)

  • SAP Note 3437774 ‚Äì Functional changes (tight dependency with 3433207)

‚ö†Ô∏è Important: Notes 3433207 and 3437774 are tightly coupled and must be installed together.

After implementing these notes, the SE84 screen opens normally and the dump no longer occurs.

SAP has also published a KBA referencing this defect:

  • KBA 3703259 ‚Äì ALV: OBJECTS_OBJREF_NOT_ASSIGNED_NO dump for CL_SALV_GUI_SLIS_FACTORY in SE84

So the resolution is simply to apply the above SAP Notes.

entry.title: AA347 Error When Posting MIRO in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ‚Äì FI-AA Fiscal Year Not Updated
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I am attempting to post a vendor invoice using transaction MIRO, and I am receiving the following error message:

‚ÄúCannot post to fixed assets in company code XXXX and fiscal year 2026.
Message No.: AA347
Diagnosis: The fiscal year change has not yet been performed in Fixed Asset Accounting for company code XXXX.
Procedure: Verify the reference date.‚Äù

This issue started after migrating to SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

The fiscal year 2025 has already been closed. However, I observed the following:

  • Transaction AJRW is not available in the system.

  • In transaction OAAQ, the fiscal year for the company code still shows 2025.

  • All functional checks were performed (AJAB, OB52, OAAQ, posting dates).

  • The root cause identified is that the FI-AA technical fiscal year in table T093C (field LGJAHR ‚Äì Current Fiscal Year) remains in 2025, although it should be 2026.

Due to this inconsistency, the MIRO posting cannot be completed.

I kindly request SAP Support to realign the FI-AA fiscal year to 2026 in order to resolve this issue and allow the MIRO posting to be processed successfully.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,
Ronald Onton
